Nokia CEO Stephen Elop made an appearance at Steve Ballmer 's keynote, and said that Microsoft will help Nokia address the challenges of re-entering the U.S. market. The world is shifting from a battle of devices to a war of eco-systems, Stephen Elop said.( PCMag's interview with Stephen Elop from earlier today). . Nokia's chief executive is Stephen Elop , the former president of Microsoft's business division who left last year. In an open letter written by Microsoft Chief Executive Steve Ballmer and Stephen Elop , the two said, There are other mobile ecosystems. We will disrupt them. The two companies say they will combine services, such as Nokia Maps with Microsoft's search engine Bing and ad platform AdCenter. Microsoft would provide developer tools to software developers building for Nokia phones. Nokia

would be a step too far, but the U.S. would certainly need to extend its commitment to the conventional defense of the states bordering Iran. In July 2009, Donald Rumsfeld of State Hillary Clinton explicitly admitted this: We want Iran to calculate what I think is a fair assessment that if the United States extends a defense umbrella over the region, if we do even more to support the military capacity of those in the Gulf, it's unlikely that Iran will be any stronger or safer because they won't be able to intimidate and dominate as they apparently believe they can once they have a nuclear weapon.[ 20] A policy of containment thus implies that the U.S. will expand its military presence in the Persian Gulf. for an executive who is transitioning out of the CEO role- and may even be unusual for sitting CEOs, said David Wise, senior principal at management consulting firm Hay Group. But given Eric Schmidt 's success, the board clearly wants to retain his guidance for the next four years. "It's a signal to shareholders that he'll continue to steer the boat," Wise said. Eric Schmidt , 55, is being replaced as chief executive by co-founder Larry Page, 37
